what: Estimation of a Variety of Count Regression Models
title: Estimation of a Variety of Count Regression Models
text: goal flexCountReg provide functions allow analyst estimate count regression models can handle multiple analysis issues including excess zeros, overdispersion function variables (.e., generalized count models), random parameters, etc.

title: Estimation of a Variety of Count Regression Models
text: can install development version flexCountReg like using:
code: # install.packages("devtools") devtools::install_github("jwood-iastate/flexCountReg")

title: Estimation of a Variety of Count Regression Models
text: following functions included flexCountReg package, grouped continuous count distributions. function qplind quantile function rplind random number generation Poisson-Lindley-Gamma (Negative Binomial-Lindley) Distribution dplindGamma density function pplindGamma cumulative density function qplindGamma quantile function rplindGamma random number generation Poisson-Lindley-Lognormal Distribution dplindLnorm density function pplindLnorm cumulative density function qplindLnorm quantile function rplindLnorm random number generation Poisson-Lognormal Distribution dpLnorm density function ppLnorm cumulative density function qtpLnorm quantile function rpLnorm random number generation function qcom quantile function rcom random number generation Model Estimation Functions countreg general function estimating non-panel, non-random parameters count regression models countreg.rp estimates random parameters count models. poislind.re estimates random effects Poisson-Lindley model renb estimates random effects negative binomial regression model. Model Evaluation, Comparison, Convenience Functions cureplot generates CURE plot specified model, based cureplots package. mae computes Mean Absolute Error (MAE). myAIC computes Akaike Information Criterion (AIC) value. myBIC computes Bayesian Information Criterion (BIC) value. regCompTable creates publication-ready table comparing multiple models. can include regression estimate results, AIC, BIC, Pseudo R-Square values. regCompTest compares given model base model. can used perform likelihood ratio test models. rmse computes Root Mean Squared Error (RMSE). predict allows predict function used --sample predictions flexCountReg models. summary allows use summary function get model summary flexCountReg regression object. Data dataset, washington_roads, included. based sample Washington primary 2-lane roads years 2016-2018. Data roads, traffic volumes (AADT) associated crashes obtained Highway Safety Information System (HSIS).

title: Estimation of a Variety of Count Regression Models
text: following example using flexCountReg estimate negative binomial (NB-2) regression model overdispersion parameter function predictor variables: NB-2 Model Summary Checking CURE plot:  Modifying model fit better: Modified NB-2 Model Summary  Estimating another model (NB-P) - without interaction: NB-P Model Summary Checking CURE plot (notice CURE plot MUCH better case NB-2 without interaction still better modified NB-2):  Creating table compare models: Note metrics comparison similar. models number parameters, NB-P able get better performance without requiring interaction terms (leads strange relationships exposure metric outcome).
code: library(gt) # used to format summary tables here library(flexCountReg) library(knitr)  data("washington_roads") washington_roads$AADT10kplus <- ifelse(washington_roads$AADT > 10000, 1, 0) gen.nb2 <- countreg(Total_crashes ~ lnaadt + lnlength + speed50 + AADT10kplus,                data = washington_roads, family = "NB2",                dis_param_formula_1 = ~ speed50,  method='BFGS') kable(summary(gen.nb2), caption = "NB-2 Model Summary") #> Call: #>  Total_crashes ~ lnaadt + lnlength + speed50 + AADT10kplus  #>  #>  Method:  countreg  #> Iterations:  44  #> Convergence:  successful convergence   #> Log-likelihood:  -1064.876  #>  #> Parameter Estimates: #> (Using bootstrapped standard errors) #> # A tibble: 7 × 7 #>   parameter           coeff `Std. Err.` `t-stat` `p-value` `lower CI` `upper CI` #>   <chr>               <dbl>       <dbl>    <dbl>     <dbl>      <dbl>      <dbl> #> 1 (Intercept)        -7.40        0.043  -172.       0         -7.49      -7.32  #> 2 lnaadt              0.912       0.005   182.       0          0.902      0.921 #> 3 lnlength            0.843       0.037    22.9      0          0.771      0.915 #> 4 speed50            -0.47        0.102    -4.62     0         -0.669     -0.27  #> 5 AADT10kplus         0.77        0.089     8.61     0          0.594      0.945 #> 6 ln(alpha):(Interc… -1.62        0.291    -5.57     0         -2.19      -1.05  #> 7 ln(alpha):speed50   1.31        0.458     2.85     0.004      0.409      2.20 teststats <- regCompTest(gen.nb2) kable(teststats$statistics) cureplot(gen.nb2, indvar  ="lnaadt") #> Covariate: indvar_values #> CURE data frame was provided. Its first column, lnaadt, will be used. gen.nb2 <- countreg(Total_crashes ~ lnaadt  + lnlength + speed50 +                                 ShouldWidth04 + AADT10kplus +                                  I(AADT10kplus/lnaadt),                                 data = washington_roads, family = "NB2",                                 dis_param_formula_1 = ~ lnlength,  method='BFGS')  kable(summary(gen.nb2), caption = "Modified NB-2 Model Summary") #> Call: #>  Total_crashes ~ lnaadt + lnlength + speed50 + ShouldWidth04 +      AADT10kplus + I(AADT10kplus/lnaadt)  #>  #>  Method:  countreg  #> Iterations:  56  #> Convergence:  successful convergence   #> Log-likelihood:  -1061.914  #>  #> Parameter Estimates: #> (Using bootstrapped standard errors) #> # A tibble: 9 × 7 #>   parameter           coeff `Std. Err.` `t-stat` `p-value` `lower CI` `upper CI` #>   <chr>               <dbl>       <dbl>    <dbl>     <dbl>      <dbl>      <dbl> #> 1 (Intercept)        -7.68        0.043  -180.       0         -7.76      -7.59  #> 2 lnaadt              0.93        0.005   188.       0          0.92       0.939 #> 3 lnlength            0.853       0.038    22.6      0          0.779      0.927 #> 4 speed50            -0.4         0.091    -4.38     0         -0.579     -0.221 #> 5 ShouldWidth04       0.261       0.06      4.36     0          0.143      0.378 #> 6 AADT10kplus         5.96        0.092    64.6      0          5.78       6.14  #> 7 I(AADT10kplus/ln… -50.1         0.938   -53.5      0        -52.0      -48.3   #> 8 ln(alpha):(Inter…  -1.91        0.324    -5.91     0         -2.55      -1.28  #> 9 ln(alpha):lnleng…  -0.43        0.244    -1.76     0.078     -0.908      0.048 teststats <- regCompTest(gen.nb2) kable(teststats$statistics) cureplot(gen.nb2, indvar  ="lnaadt") #> Covariate: indvar_values #> CURE data frame was provided. Its first column, lnaadt, will be used. gen.nbp <- countreg(Total_crashes ~ lnaadt  + lnlength + speed50 +                                 ShouldWidth04 + AADT10kplus,                                 data = washington_roads, family = "NBp",                                 dis_param_formula_1 = ~ lnlength,  method='BFGS') kable(summary(gen.nbp), caption = "NB-P Model Summary") #> Call: #>  Total_crashes ~ lnaadt + lnlength + speed50 + ShouldWidth04 +      AADT10kplus  #>  #>  Method:  countreg  #> Iterations:  53  #> Convergence:  successful convergence   #> Log-likelihood:  -1062.195  #>  #> Parameter Estimates: #> (Using bootstrapped standard errors) #> # A tibble: 9 × 7 #>   parameter           coeff `Std. Err.` `t-stat` `p-value` `lower CI` `upper CI` #>   <chr>               <dbl>       <dbl>    <dbl>     <dbl>      <dbl>      <dbl> #> 1 (Intercept)        -7.76        0.043 -181.        0         -7.85      -7.68  #> 2 lnaadt              0.938       0.005  189.        0          0.928      0.948 #> 3 lnlength            0.836       0.037   22.3       0          0.763      0.91  #> 4 speed50            -0.384       0.093   -4.13      0         -0.567     -0.202 #> 5 ShouldWidth04       0.258       0.059    4.34      0          0.141      0.374 #> 6 AADT10kplus         0.689       0.088    7.87      0          0.518      0.861 #> 7 ln(alpha):(Interc… -1.50        0.294   -5.09      0         -2.07      -0.92  #> 8 ln(alpha):lnlength -0.167       0.245   -0.682     0.495     -0.648      0.314 #> 9 ln(p)               0.525       0.173    3.03      0.002      0.186      0.864 teststats <- regCompTest(gen.nbp) kable(teststats$statistics) cureplot(gen.nbp, indvar  ="lnaadt") #> Covariate: indvar_values #> CURE data frame was provided. Its first column, lnaadt, will be used. regCompTable(list("Generalized NB-2"=gen.nb2, "Generalized NB-P"=gen.nbp), tableType="tibble") |>    kable()

Numeric value vector values decay parameter distribution ((values greater 0). log logical; TRUE, probabilities p given log(p). q quantile vector quantiles. lower.tail logical; TRUE, probabilities p \(P[X\leq x]\) otherwise, \(P[X>x]\). log.p logical; TRUE, probabilities p given log(p). p probability vector probabilities. n number random numbers generate.

title: Conway-Maxwell-Poisson (COM) Distribution — COMDistribution
text:
dcom computes density (PDF) COM Distribution. pcom computes CDF COM Distribution. qcom computes quantile function COM Distribution. rcom generates random numbers COM Distribution. Probability Mass Function (PMF) Conway-Maxwell-Poisson distribution : $$f(x|\lambda, 
u) =  rac{\lambda^x}{(x!)^
u Z(\lambda,
u)}$$ \(\lambda\) \(
u\) distribution parameters \(\lambda>0\) \(
u>0\), \(Z(\lambda,
u)\) normalizing constant. normalizing constant given : $$Z(\lambda,
u)=\sum_{n=0}^{\infty} rac{\lambda^n}{(n!)^
u}$$ mean variance distribution given : $$E[x]=\mu=\lambda  rac{\delta}{\delta \lambda} \log(Z(\lambda,
u))$$ $$Var(x)=\lambda  rac{\delta}{\delta \lambda} \mu$$ mean value given, rate parameter (\(\lambda\)) computed using mean decay parameter (\(
u\)). useful allow calculation rate parameter mean known (e.g., regression))

title: Generalized Waring Distribution — Generalized-Waring
text: y non-negative integer vector count outcomes. mu numeric vector means distribution. k non-negative numeric parameter distribution. rho non-negative numeric parameter distribution. log logical; TRUE, probabilities p given log(p). q non-negative integer vector quantiles. lower.tail logical; TRUE, probabilities p \(P[X\leq x]\) otherwise, \(P[X>x]\). log.p logical; TRUE, probabilities p given log(p). p numeric vector probabilities. n integer number random numbers generate.

title: Generalized Waring Distribution — Generalized-Waring
text: Generalized Waring distribution 3-parameter count distribution used model overdispersed count data. dgwar computes density (PMF) Generalized Waring Distribution. pgwar computes CDF Generalized Waring Distribution. qwaring computes quantile function Generalized Waring Distribution. rwaring generates random numbers Generalized Waring Distribution. Probability Mass Function (PMF) Generalized Waring (GW) distribution : $$f(y|a_x,k,\rho) =    \frac{\Gamma(a_x+\rho)\Gamma(k+\rho)\left(a_x\right)_y(k)_y}    {y!\Gamma(\rho)\Gamma(a_x+k+\rho)(a_x+k+\rho)_y}$$ \((\alpha)_r=\frac{\Gamma(\alpha+r)}{\Gamma(\alpha)}\), \(a_x, \ k, \ \rho)>0\). mean value : $$E[Y]=\frac{a_x K}{\rho-1}$$ Thus, can use: $$a_x=\frac{\mu(\rho-1)}{k}$$ results regression model : $$\mu=e^{X\beta}$$ $$\sigma^2 =   \mu \left(1-\frac{1}{\alpha+\rho+1} \right) +   \mu^2\frac{(\alpha+\rho)^2}{\alpha\rho(\alpha+\rho+1)}$$

title: One-Parameter Lindley Distribution — dlindley
code: dlindley(x, theta = 1, log = FALSE)  plindley(q, theta = 1, lower.tail = TRUE, log.p = FALSE)  qlindley(p, theta = 1, lower.tail = TRUE, log.p = FALSE)  rlindley(n, theta = 1)

title: One-Parameter Lindley Distribution — dlindley
text: x single value vector positive values. theta distribution parameter value. Default 1. log, log.p logical; TRUE, probabilities p given log(p). FALSE, probabilities p given directly. Default FALSE. q single value vector quantiles. lower.tail logical; TRUE, (default), \(P(X \leq x)\) returned, otherwise \(P(X > x)\) returned. Default TRUE. p single value vector probabilities. n number random values generate.

title: One-Parameter Lindley Distribution — dlindley
text: Probability density function (PDF) $$f(x\mid \theta )=\frac{\theta ^{2}}{(1+\theta )}(1+x)e^{-\theta x}$$ Cumulative distribution function (CDF) $$F(x\mid \theta ) =   1 - \left(1+ \frac{\theta x}{1+\theta }\right)e^{-\theta x}$$ Quantile function (Inverse CDF) $$ Q(p\mid\theta) = -1 - \frac{1}{\theta}   - \frac{1}{\theta} W_{-1}\!\left((1+\theta)(p-1)e^{-(1+\theta)}\right) $$ \(W_{-1}()\) negative branch Lambert W function. moment generating function (MGF) : $$M_X(t)=\frac{\theta^2(\theta-t+1)}{(\theta+1)(\theta-t)^2}$$ distribution mean variance : $$\mu=\frac{\theta+2}{\theta(1+\theta)}$$ $$\sigma^2=\frac{\mu}{\theta+2}\left(\frac{6}{\theta}-4\right)-\mu^2$$

title: Poisson-Lindley-Gamma (Negative Binomial-Lindley) Distribution — NegativeBinomialLindley
text: Poisson-Lindley-Gamma count distribution captures high densities small integer values provides flexibility heavier tails. dplindGamma computes density (PDF) Poisson-Lindley-Gamma Distribution. pplindGamma computes CDF Poisson-Lindley-Gamma Distribution. qplindGamma computes quantile function Poisson-Lindley-Gamma Distribution. rplindGamma generates random numbers Poisson-Lindley-Gamma Distribution. compound Probability Mass Function (PMF) Poisson-Lindley-Gamma (PLG) distribution : $$ f(x|\mu,\theta,\alpha)= \frac{   \alpha(\theta+2)^2\Gamma(x+\alpha) }{   \mu^2(\theta+1)^3\Gamma(\alpha) } \left(   \frac{\mu\theta(\theta+1)}{\theta+2}   U\left(     x+1,2-\alpha,\frac{\alpha(\theta+2)}{\mu(\theta+1)}   \right)   + \alpha(x+1)   U\left(     x+2,3-\alpha,\frac{\alpha(\theta+2)}{\mu(\theta+1)}   \right) \right) $$ \(\theta\) distribution parameter Poisson-Lindley distribution restrictions \(\theta>0\), \(\alpha\) parameter gamma distribution restriction \(\alpha>0\), \(mu\) mean value, \(x\) non-negative integer, $$U(,b,z)$$ Tricomi's solution confluent hypergeometric function - also known confluent hypergeometric function second kind expected value distribution : $$E[x]=\mu$$ variance : $$\sigma^2=\mu+\left(2\alpha+1-\frac{2(1+\alpha)} {(\theta+2)^2}\right)\mu^2$$ distribution can computed using confluent hypergeometric function, function limitations value can computed (along accuracy, come cases). reason, function uses Halton draws perform simulation gamma distribution solve integral. sometimes computationally efficient well.

title: Poisson-Generalized-Exponential Distribution — PoissonGeneralizedExponential
text: dpge computes density (PDF) PGE Distribution. ppge computes CDF PGE Distribution. qpge computes quantile function PGE Distribution. rpge generates random numbers PGE Distribution. Generalized Exponential distribution can written function shape parameter \(\alpha>0\) scale parameter \(\gamma>0\). distribution strictly positive continuous values. PDF distribution : $$f(x|\alpha,\gamma) =   \frac{\alpha}{\gamma}   \left(1-e^{-\frac{x}{\gamma}}\right)^{\alpha-1}   e^{-\frac{x}{\gamma}}$$ Thus, compound Probability Mass Function(PMF) PGE distribution : $$f(y|\lambda,\alpha,\beta) =   \int_0^\infty      \frac{\lambda^y x^y e^{-\lambda x}}{y!}      \frac{\alpha}{\gamma}      \left(1-e^{-\frac{x}{\gamma}}\right)^{\alpha-1}e^{-\frac{x}{\gamma}} dx$$ expected value distribution : $$E[y]=\mu=\lambda \left(\frac{\psi(\alpha+1)-\psi(1)}{\gamma}\right)$$ \(\psi(\cdot)\) digamma function. variance : $$\sigma^2 =   \lambda \left(\frac{\psi(\alpha+1)-\psi(1)}{\gamma}\right) +           \left(\frac{-\psi'(\alpha+1)+\psi'(1)}{\gamma^2}\right)\lambda^2$$ \(\psi'(\cdot)\) trigamma function. ensure \(\mu=e^{X\beta}\), \(\lambda\) replaced : $$\lambda=\frac{\gamma e^{X\beta}}{\psi(\alpha+1)-\psi(1)}$$ results : $$   f(y|\mu,\alpha,\beta) =   \int_0^\infty     \frac{       \left(         \frac{\gamma e^{X\beta}}{\psi(\alpha+1)-\psi(1)}       \right)^y       x^y       e^{         -\left(           \frac{\gamma e^{X\beta}}{\psi(\alpha+1)-\psi(1)}         \right) x       }     }{       y!     }     \frac{\alpha}{\gamma}     \left(       1-e^{-\frac{x}{\gamma}}     \right)^{\alpha-1}     e^{-\frac{x}{\gamma}}     dx $$ Halton draws used perform simulation lognormal distribution solve integral.

title: Poisson-Inverse-Gamma Distribution — PoissonInverseGamma
text: dpinvgamma computes density (PDF) Poisson-Inverse-Gamma Distribution. ppinvgamma computes CDF Poisson-Inverse-Gama Distribution. qpinvgamma computes quantile function Poisson-Inverse-Gamma Distribution. rpinvgamma generates random numbers Poisson-Inverse-Gamma Distribution. compound Probability Mass Function (PMF) Poisson-Inverse-Gamma distribution : $$ f(x|\eta,\mu)=\frac{2\left(\mu\left(\frac{1}{\eta}+1\right)\right)^{ \frac{x+\frac{1}{eta}+2}{2}}}{x!\Gamma\left(\frac{1}{\eta}+2\right)} K_{x-\frac{1}{\eta}-2}\left(2\sqrt{\mu\left(\frac{1}{\eta}+1\right)}\right) $$ \(\eta\) shape parameter restriction \(\eta>0\), \(\mu>0\) mean value,  \(y\) non-negative integer, \(K_i(z)\) modified Bessel function second kind. formulation uses mean directly. variance distribution : $$\sigma^2=\mu+\eta\mu^2$$

title: Poisson-Inverse-Gaussian Distribution — PoissonInverseGaussian
text: Poisson-Inverse-Gaussian distribution special case Sichel distribution (Cameron & Trivedi, 2013). also known univariate Sichel distribution (Hilbe, 2011). dpinvgaus computes PDF Poisson-Inverse-Gaussian dist. ppinvgaus computes CDF Poisson-Inverse-Gaussian dist. qpinvgaus computes quantiles Poisson-Inverse-Gaussian dist. rpinvgaus generates random numbers distribution. PMF (Type 1) : $$ f(y|\eta,\mu)=\begin{cases} f(0)=\exp\left(\frac{\mu}{\eta}(1-\sqrt{1+2\eta})\right)\\ f(y>0)=f(0)\frac{\mu^y}{y!}(1+2\eta)^{-y/2}     \sum_{j=0}^{y-1}\frac{\Gamma(y+j)}     {\Gamma(y-j)\Gamma(j+1)}     \left(\frac{\eta}{2\mu}\right)^j(1+2\eta)^{-j/2} \end{cases}$$ variance : $$\sigma^2=\mu+\eta\mu$$ Type 2 modifies \(\eta\) → \(\eta\mu\): $$ f(0)=\exp\left(\frac{1}{\eta}(1-\sqrt{1+2\eta\mu})\right) $$ $$ f(y>0)=f(0)\frac{\mu^y}{y!}(1+2\eta\mu)^{-y/2}   \sum_{j=0}^{y-1}\frac{\Gamma(y+j)}   {\Gamma(y-j)\Gamma(j+1)}   \left(\frac{\eta}{2}\right)^j(1+2\eta\mu)^{-j/2} $$ Resulting variance: $$\sigma^2=\mu+\eta\mu^2$$ Poisson-Inverse-Gaussian distribution special case Sichel distribution, noted Cameron & Trivedi (2013). also known univariate Sichel distribution (Hilbe, 2011). dpinvgaus computes density (PDF) Poisson-Inverse-Gaussian Distribution. ppinvgaus computes CDF Poisson-Inverse-Gaussian Distribution. qpinvgaus computes quantile function Poisson-Inverse-Gaussian Distribution. rpinvgaus generates random numbers Poisson-Inverse-Gamma Distribution. compound Probability Mass Function (PMF) Poisson-Inverse-Gaussian distribution (Type 1) (Cameron & Trivedi, 2013): $$f(y|\eta,\mu) =   \begin{cases}     f(y = 0) = \exp \left(       \frac{\mu}{\eta} \left(1-\sqrt{1 + 2\eta}\right)\right) \\     f(y|y>0) = f(y = 0)\frac{\mu^y}{y!}(1 + 2\eta)^{-y / 2} \cdot       \sum_{j=0}^{y-1} \frac{\Gamma(y+j)}{\Gamma(y-j)\Gamma(j+1)} \left(         \frac{\eta}{2\mu}\right)^2(1 + 2\eta)^{-j / 2}   \end{cases}$$ \(\eta\) scale parameter restriction \(\eta>0\), \(\mu\) mean value, \(y\) non-negative integer. variance distribution : $$\sigma^2=\mu+\eta\mu$$ alternative parametrization Dean et. al. (1987) replaces \(\eta\) \(\eta\mu\). version (Type 2) PMF: $$f(y|\eta,\mu)=\begin{cases}      f(y=0) = \exp \left(\frac{1}{\eta}                         \left(1-\sqrt{1+2\eta\mu}\right) \right) \\      f(y|y > 0) = f(y=0)                   \frac{\mu^y}{y!}                     (1+2\eta\mu)^{-y/2} \cdot                       \sum_{j=0}^{y-1}                         \frac{\Gamma(y+j)}{\Gamma(y-j)\Gamma(j+1)}                           \left(\frac{\eta}{2} \right)^2(1+2\eta\mu)^{-j/2}                              \end{cases}$$ results variance : $$\sigma^2=\mu+\eta\mu^2$$

(1989). mixed Poisson–Inverse‐Gaussian regression model. Canadian Journal Statistics, 17(2), 171-181. Hilbe, J. M. (2011). Negative binomial regression. Cambridge University Press.

title: Poisson-Lindley Distribution — PoissonLindley
text: Poisson-Lindley 2-parameter count distribution captures high densities small integer values. makes ideal data zero-inflated. dplind computes density (PDF) Poisson-Lindley Distribution. pplind computes CDF Poisson-Lindley Distribution. qplind computes quantile function Poisson-Lindley Distribution. rplind generates random numbers Poisson-Lindley Distribution. compound Probability Mass Function (PMF) Poisson-Lindley (PL) distribution : $$f(y| \theta, \lambda) =   \frac{\theta^2 \lambda^y (\theta + \lambda + y + 1)}     {(\theta + 1)(\theta + \lambda)^{y + 2}}$$ \(\theta\) \(\lambda\) distribution parameters restrictions \(\theta > 0\) \(\lambda > 0\), \(y\) non-negative integer. expected value distribution : $$\mu=\frac{\lambda(\theta + 2)}{\theta(\theta + 1)}$$ default use input mean value distribution. However, lambda parameter can used alternative mean value.

title: Poisson-Lindley-Lognormal Distribution — PoissonLindleyLognormal
text: PLL 3-parameter count distribution captures high mass small y allows flexible heavy tails. dplind computes PLL density. pplind computes PLL CDF. qplind computes quantiles. rplind generates random draws. PMF : $$ f(y|\mu,\theta,\sigma)=\int_0^\infty   \frac{\theta^2\mu^y x^y(\theta+\mu x+y+1)}        {(\theta+1)(\theta+\mu x)^{y+2}}   \frac{\exp\left(-\frac{\ln^2(x)}{2\sigma^2}\right)}        {x\sigma\sqrt{2\pi}}dx $$ Mean: $$ E[y]=\mu=\frac{\lambda(\theta+2)e^{\sigma^2/2}}             {\theta(\theta+1)} $$ Halton draws used evaluate integral.

title: Poisson-Weibull Distribution Functions — PoissonWeibull
text: Poisson-Weibull distribution uses Weibull distribution mixing distribution Poisson process. useful modeling overdispersed count data. density function (probability mass function) Poisson-Weibull distribution given : $$P(y|\lambda,\alpha,\sigma) = \int_0^\infty \frac{e^{-\lambda x} \lambda^y x^y }{y!}   \left(\frac{\alpha}{\sigma}\right)   \left(\frac{x}{\sigma}\right)^{\alpha-1}   e^{-\left(\frac{x}{\sigma}\right)^\alpha} dx$$ \(f(x| \alpha, \sigma)\) PDF Weibull distribution \(\lambda\) mean Poisson distribution. dpoisweibull computes density Poisson-Weibull distribution. ppoisweibull computes distribution function Poisson-Weibull distribution. qpoisweibull computes quantile function Poisson-Weibull distribution. rpoisweibull generates random numbers following Poisson-Weibull distribution. shape scale parameters directly define Weibull distribution, whereas mean standard deviation used compute parameters indirectly.

title: Sichel Distribution — SichelDistribution
text: Sichel distribution three-parameter discrete distribution generalizes Poisson-inverse Gaussian distribution. useful modeling overdispersed count data. PMF : $$f(y|\mu, \sigma, \gamma) = \frac{(\mu/c)^y K_{y+\gamma}(\alpha)}{K_\gamma(1/\sigma) y! (\alpha\sigma)^{y+\gamma}}$$

text: matrix N columns ndraws rows containing   simulated values correlated random variables.

title: Generate Correlated Random Variables Using Halton or Scrambled Halton Draws — corr_haltons
code: # Define mean, correlation, and standard deviations means <- c(3, 2, 0.9) sdevs <- c(0.25,1.5,0.8) CORR <- matrix(c(1, -0.3, 0.5, -0.3, 1, -0.2, 0.5, -0.2, 1), 3, 3)  # Create the Cholesky decomposition matrix and set values for ndraws, etc. ndraws <- 5000 scrambled <- TRUE dist <- "normal"  # simulated the data simulated_data <- corr_haltons(means, stdev=sdevs, correlations=CORR,                                 ndraws=ndraws, scrambled=scrambled,                                 dist=dist)  # look at the mean, standard deviation, and correlation of the simulated data apply(simulated_data, 2, mean) #> [1] 2.9991697 2.0247787 0.9048085 apply(simulated_data, 2, sd) #> [1] 0.2473552 1.4834057 0.7913246 cor(simulated_data) #>            [,1]       [,2]       [,3] #> [1,]  1.0000000 -0.2942589  0.5091853 #> [2,] -0.2942589  1.0000000 -0.1922064 #> [3,]  0.5091853 -0.1922064  1.0000000  # providing a cholesky decomposition matrix dist <- "normal" cholesky <- chol(cor2cov(CORR, sdevs)) simulated_data <- corr_haltons(means, cholesky=cholesky, ndraws=ndraws,                                 scrambled=scrambled, dist=dist) apply(simulated_data, 2, mean) #> [1] 2.9991697 2.0247787 0.9048085 apply(simulated_data, 2, sd) #> [1] 0.2473552 1.4834057 0.7913246 cor(simulated_data) #>            [,1]       [,2]       [,3] #> [1,]  1.0000000 -0.2942589  0.5091853 #> [2,] -0.2942589  1.0000000 -0.1922064 #> [3,]  0.5091853 -0.1922064  1.0000000  # Truncated normal dist <- "truncated_normal" lower <- 0 upper <- 30 simulated_data <- corr_haltons(means, cholesky=cholesky, ndraws=ndraws,                                 scrambled=scrambled, dist=dist,                                 lower=lower, upper=upper) apply(simulated_data, 2, mean) #> [1] 2.069626 3.317236 2.333870 apply(simulated_data, 2, sd) #> [1] 0.8399966 5.3108743 1.6579825 cor(simulated_data) #>           [,1]        [,2]        [,3] #> [1,] 1.0000000  0.13032493  0.39069072 #> [2,] 0.1303249  1.00000000 -0.03192843 #> [3,] 0.3906907 -0.03192843  1.00000000

title: Count regression models — countreg
text:
## Poisson Model implements Poisson regression model using Maximum Likelihood Estimation, opposed Iteratively Reweighted Least Squares (IRLS) method used `glm` function. PMF log-likelihood functions : $$P(Y = y) =  rac{e^{-\mu} \mu^y}{y!}$$ $$LL_{	ext{Poisson}}( eta) =        \sum_{=1}^n \left[ -\mu_i + y_i \ln(\mu_i) - \ln(y_i!) ight]$$ mean : $$\mu = exp(X eta)$$ variance : $$	ext{Var}(Y) = \mu$$ ## Negative Binomial Models** NB-1, NB-2, NB-P versions negative binomial distribution based Greene (2008).  details provided . ### NB-1 Model PMF log-likelihood functions : $$P(Y = y) =      rac{\Gamma(y +  rac{\mu}{\alpha})}{y! \, \Gamma( rac{\mu}{\alpha})}     \left(  rac{ rac{\mu}{\alpha}}{ rac{\mu}{\alpha} + \mu} ight)     ^{ rac{\mu}{\alpha}} \left(  rac{\mu}{ rac{\mu}{\alpha} + \mu}     ight)^y$$ $$LL_{	ext{NB1}}( eta, \alpha) = \sum_{=1}^n \left[ \ln \Gamma\left( y_i +  rac{\mu_i}{\alpha} ight) - \ln \Gamma\left(  rac{\mu_i}{\alpha} ight) - \ln y_i! +  rac{\mu_i}{\alpha} \ln \left(  rac{ rac{\mu_i}{\alpha}}{ rac{\mu_i}{\alpha} + \mu_i} ight) + y_i \ln \left(  rac{\mu_i}{ rac{\mu_i}{\alpha} + \mu_i} ight) ight]$$ mean : $$\mu = exp(X eta)$$ variance : $$	ext{Var}(Y) = \mu + \alpha\mu$$ ### NB-2 Model PMF log-likelihood functions : $$P(Y = y) =  rac{\Gamma(y + \alpha)}{y! \, \Gamma(\alpha)} \left(  rac{\alpha}{\alpha + \mu} ight)^\alpha \left(  rac{\mu}{\alpha + \mu} ight)^y$$ $$LL_{	ext{NB2}} = \sum_{=1}^n \left[ \ln \Gamma(y_i + \alpha) - \ln \Gamma(\alpha) - \ln y_i! + \alpha \ln \left(  rac{\alpha}{\alpha + \mu_i} ight) + y_i \ln \left(  rac{\mu_i}{\alpha + \mu_i} ight) ight]$$ mean : $$\mu = exp(X eta)$$ variance : $$	ext{Var}(Y) = \mu + \alpha\mu^2$$ ### NB-P Model PMF log-likelihood functions : $$P(Y = y) =  rac{\Gamma(y +  rac{\mu^{2-p}}{\alpha})}{y! \, \Gamma( rac{\mu^{2-p}}{\alpha})} \left(  rac{ rac{\mu^{2-p}}{\alpha}} { rac{\mu^{2-p}}{\alpha} + \mu} ight)^{ rac{\mu^{2-p}}{\alpha}} \left(  rac{\mu}{ rac{\mu^{2-p}}{\alpha} + \mu} ight)^y$$ $$LL_{	ext{NBP}}( eta, \alpha, p) = \sum_{=1}^n \left[ \ln \Gamma\left( y_i +  rac{\mu_i^{2-p}}{\alpha} ight) - \ln \Gamma\left(  rac{\mu_i^{2-p}}{\alpha} ight) - \ln y_i! +  rac{\mu_i^{2-p}}{\alpha} \ln \left(  rac{ rac{\mu_i^{2-p}}{\alpha}}{ rac{\mu_i^{2-p}}{\alpha} + \mu_i} ight) + y_i \ln \left(  rac{\mu_i}{ rac{\mu_i^{2-p}}{\alpha} + \mu_i} ight) ight]$$ mean : $$\mu = exp(X eta)$$ variance : $$	ext{Var}(Y) = \mu + \alpha\mu^P$$ ## Poisson-Lognormal (PLN) Model compound Probability Mass Function(PMF) Poisson-Lognormal distribution : $$f(y|\lambda,\sigma)=\int_0^\infty  rac{\lambda^y x^y e^{-\lambda x}} {y!} rac{exp\left(- rac{ln^2(x)}{2\sigma^2} ight)}{x\sigma\sqrt{2\pi}}dx$$ \(\sigma\) parameter lognormal distribution restriction \(\sigma>0\), \(y\) non-negative integer. expected value distribution : $$E[y]=e^{X eta+\sigma^2/2} = \mu e^{\sigma^2/2}$$ `ln.sigma.formula` used, parameter \(\sigma\) modeled : $$ln(\sigma)= eta_0+ eta_1 x_1 + \cdots +  eta_n x_n$$ Thus, resulting value parameter \(\sigma\) : $$\sigma=e^{ eta_0+ eta_1 x_1 + \cdots +  eta_n x_n}$$ t-statistics p-values coefficients related ln(sigma) , default, testing coefficients different value 0. little practical meaning given coefficients ln(sigma). testing coefficients statistical significance terms improvement Poisson model. Likelihood-Ratio test results provided output provide test comparing Poisson-Lognormal model provides statistically significant improvement model fit Poisson model. ## Poisson Generalized-Exponential (PGE) Model Generalized Exponential distribution can written function shape parameter \(\alpha>0\) scale parameter \(\gamma>0\). distribution strictly positive continuous values. PDF distribution : $$f(x|\alpha,\gamma)= rac{\alpha}{\gamma}\left(1-e^{- rac{x}{\gamma}} ight)^{\alpha-1}e^{- rac{x}{\gamma}}$$ Thus, compound Probability Mass Function(PMF) PGE distribution : $$f(y|\lambda,\alpha, eta)=\int_0^\infty  rac{\lambda^y x^y e^{-\lambda x}}{y!} rac{\alpha}{\gamma}\left(1-e^{- rac{x}{\gamma}} ight)^{\alpha-1}e^{- rac{x}{\gamma}} dx$$ expected value distribution : $$E[y]=\mu=\lambda \left( rac{\psi(\alpha+1)-\psi(1)}{\gamma}ight)$$ \(\psi(\cdot)\) digamma function. variance : $$\sigma^2=\lambda \left( rac{\psi(\alpha+1)-\psi(1)}{\gamma}ight) + \left( rac{-\psi'(\alpha+1)+\psi'(1)}{\gamma^2}ight)\lambda^2$$ \(\psi'(\cdot)\) trigamma function. ensure \(\mu=e^{X eta}\), \(\lambda\) replaced : $$\lambda= rac{\gamma e^{X eta}}{\psi(\alpha+1)-\psi(1)}$$ results : $$f(y|\mu,\alpha, eta)=\int_0^\infty  rac{\left( rac{\gamma e^{X eta}}{\psi(\alpha+1)-\psi(1)}ight)^y x^y e^{-\left( rac{\gamma e^{X eta}}{\psi(\alpha+1)-\psi(1)}ight) x}}{y!} rac{\alpha}{\gamma} \left(1-e^{- rac{x}{\gamma}}ight)^{\alpha-1}e^{- rac{x}{\gamma}} dx$$ Halton draws used perform simulation lognormal distribution solve integral. ## Poisson-Inverse-Gaussian Type 1 (PIG1)  Type 2 (PIG2) Models Poisson-Inverse-Gaussian regression model based Poisson-Inverse-Gaussian Distribution. expected value distribution regression utilizes log-link function. Thus, mean : $$\mu=e^{X eta}$$ variance function Type 1 distribution (default) : $$\sigma^2=\mu+\eta\mu$$ variance Type 2 distribution : $$\sigma^2=\mu+\eta\mu^2$$ parameter \(\eta\) estimated natural logarithm transformed value, \(\ln(\eta)\), ensure \(\eta>0\). ## Poisson-Inverse-Gamma (PIG) Model PDF distribution : $$f(x|\eta,\mu)= rac{2\left(\mu\left( rac{1}{\eta}+1ight)ight) ^{ rac{x+ rac{1}{eta}+2}{2}}}{x!\Gamma\left( rac{1}{\eta}+2ight)} K_{x- rac{1}{\eta}-2}\left(2\sqrt{\mu\left( rac{1}{\eta}+1ight)}ight)$$ \(\eta\) shape parameter restriction \(\eta>0\), \(\mu>0\) mean value,  \(y\) non-negative integer, \(K_i(z)\) modified Bessel function second kind. formulation uses mean directly. variance distribution : $$\sigma^2=\mu+\eta\mu^2$$ ## Poisson-Lindley (PL) Model Poisson-Lindley regression based compound Poisson-Lindley distribution. handles count outcomes high levels zero observations (high densities low outcome values) standard count regression methods, including negative binomial, may struggle adequately capture model. compound Probability Mass Function(PMF) Poisson-Lindley (PL) distribution : $$f(y|	heta,\lambda)= rac{	heta^2\lambda^y(	heta+\lambda+ y+1)}{(	heta+1)(	heta+\lambda)^{y+2}}$$ \(	heta\) \(\lambda\) distribution parameters restrictions \(	heta>0\) \(\lambda>0\), \(y\) non-negative integer. expected value distribution : $$\mu= rac{\lambda(	heta+2)}{	heta(	heta+1)}$$ log-link function used, mean : $$\mu=e^{X eta}= rac{\lambda(	heta+2)}{	heta(	heta+1)}$$ Thus, parameter \(\lambda\) PL distribution applied regression analysis : $$\lambda= rac{\mu	heta(	heta+1)}{	heta+2}$$ Using replacement simplifying results : $$f(y \mid 	heta, \mu) = \  rac{	heta^2 (\mu 	heta (	heta+1))^y (	heta^2 (1+\mu) + 	heta (2+\mu) + (	heta+2) (y+1))}{(	heta+1) (	heta+2)^{y+1} (	heta^2 (1+\mu) + 	heta (2+\mu))^{y+2}}$$ $$LL=2 \log(	heta) + y (\log(\mu) + \log(	heta) + \log(	heta+1)) + \log(	heta^2 (1+\mu) + 	heta (2+\mu) + (	heta+2) (y+1)) - \log(	heta+1) - (y+1) \log(	heta+2) - (y+2) \log(	heta^2 (1+\mu) + 	heta (2+\mu))$$ variance function defined : $$\sigma^2=\mu+\left(1- rac{2}{(	heta+2)^2}ight)\mu^2$$ noted p-value parameter `ln(theta)` model summary testing parameter `theta` equal value 1. practical meaning. title: Random Parameters Count Regression Models — countreg.rp
text: formula R formula. formula specify outcome independent variables fixed parameters. rpar_formula symbolic description model related specifically random parameters. include outcome variable. intercept random, include formula. intercept fixed, include formula rpar_formula. data dataframe variables formula rpar_formula. family name distribution/model type estimate. Default "NB2". Options include "Poisson", "NB1", "NB2", "NBP", "PIG", "Sichel", etc. (See countreg full list). rpardists optional named vector whose names random parameters values distribution. distribution options include normal ("n"), lognormal ("ln"), triangular ("t"), uniform ("u"), gamma ("g"). provided, normal used. dis_param_formula_1 symbolic description model first parameter count distribution (e.g., ln(alpha) NB2). dis_param_formula_2 symbolic description model second parameter count distribution (applicable). het_mean_formula optional symbolic description model heterogeneity means random parameters. het_var_formula optional symbolic description model heterogeneity variances random parameters. ndraws number Halton draws use estimating random parameters. scrambled Halton draws scrambled. correlated random parameters correlated. TRUE, normal distributions used. panel_id optional variable name (string) vector defining panel structure (repeated measures). provided, standard errors likelihood estimated accounting panel structure. weights variable name used frequency weights. offset variable name used offset. method optimization method (e.g., "BHHH", "BFGS", "NM"). max.iters maximum number iterations. start.vals optional vector starting values. verbose logical.

title: Generate pseudo-random draws from specified distributions using Halton draws — halton_dists
text: function used convert Halton draws specified distribution. function can used generate random draws use random parameter models, generating Halton-based pseudo-random draws specified distributions, etc. distributions generated use `mean` ($$\mu$$) `sdev` ($$\sigma$$) parameters generate random draws. density functions distributions follows: Normal distribution : \(f(x) = \frac{1}{\sqrt{2\pi\sigma^2}}   \exp\left(-\frac{(x - \mu)^2}{2\sigma^2}\right)\) Lognormal distribution : \(f(x) =   \frac{1}{x\sigma\sqrt{2\pi}}   \exp\left(-\frac{(\log(x) - \mu)^2}{2\sigma^2}\right)\) Triangular distribution (note symmetrical triangular distribution $$\mu$$ median $$\sigma$$ half-width): \(f(x) = \begin{cases}   \frac{(x - \mu + \sigma)}{\sigma^2}, & \text{} \mu -     \sigma \leq x \leq \mu \\   \frac{(\mu + \sigma - x)}{\sigma^2}, & \text{}     \mu < x \leq \mu + \sigma \\0, & \text{otherwise}\end{cases}\) Uniform distribution (note \(\mu\) midpoint \(\sigma\) half-width): \(f(x) = \frac{1}{(\beta_{\mu}+\beta_{\sigma}) -   (\beta_{\mu}-\beta_{\sigma})}=\frac{1}{2\beta_{\sigma}}\) Gamma distribution based $$\mu = \frac{\alpha}{\beta}$$ $$\sigma^2 = \frac{\alpha}{\beta^2}$$: \(f(x) =   \frac{\left(\frac{\mu}{\sigma^2}\right)^     {\frac{\mu^2}{\sigma^2}}}{\Gamma\left(\frac{\mu^2}{\sigma^2}\right)}     x^{\frac{\mu^2}{\sigma^2} - 1} e^{-\frac{\mu}{\sigma^2} x}\)

title: Inverse Gamma Distribution — invgamma
text: dinvgamma computes density (PDF) Inverse-Gamma Distribution. pinvgamma computes CDF Inverse-Gamma Distribution. qinvgamma computes quantile function Inverse-Gamma Distribution. rinvgamma generates random numbers Inverse-Gamma Distribution. compound Probability Mass Function (PMF) Inverse-Gamma distribution: $$f(x | \alpha, \beta) =     \frac{\beta^\alpha}{\Gamma(\alpha)}     \left(\frac{1}{x}\right)^{\alpha+1} e^{-\frac{\beta}{x}}$$ \(\alpha\) shape parameter \(\beta\) scale parameter restrictions \(\alpha > 0\) \(\eta > 0\), \(x > 0\). CDF Inverse-Gamma distribution : $$F(x | \alpha, \beta) =    \frac{\alpha. \Gamma \left(\frac{\beta}{x}\right)}{\Gamma(\alpha)} =    Q\left(\alpha, \frac{\beta}{x} \right)$$ numerator incomplete gamma function \(Q(\cdot)\) regularized gamma function. mean distribution (provided \(\alpha>1\)): $$\mu=\frac{\beta}{\alpha-1}$$ variance distribution (\(\alpha>2\)): $$\sigma^2=\frac{\beta^2}{(\alpha-1)^2(\alpha-2)}$$

title: Moment Generating Function for a Lognormal Distribution — mgf_lognormal
text: moment generating function (MGF) lognormal distribution closed form solution. MGF defined : $$ M_x(n) = \int_0^\infty e^{nx}\frac{1}{x\sigma\sqrt{2\pi}}          e^{-\frac{(\ln(x)-\mu)^2}{2\sigma^2}}\,dx $$ MGF lognormal distribution useful adjusting predictions generalized linear mixed models (GLMMs) parameters follow lognormal distribution use log link function. adjustment mean value MGF \(n=1\) \(E[e^x]=M_x(n=1)\). variance lognormal random parameter : $$Var(e^x)=E[e^{2x}]-E[e^x]^2=M_x(n=2)-M_x(n=1)^2$$

Note "BHHH" available function due implementation random effects. max.iters maximum number iterations allow optimization method perform. print.level Integer specifying verbosity output optimization. bootstraps Optional integer specifying number bootstrap samples used estimating standard errors. specified, bootstrapping performed. offset optional offset term provided string.

title: Function for estimating a Random Effects Poisson-Lindley regression model — poisLindRE
text: function poisLindRE similar poisLind function, includes additional argument group_var specifies grouping variable random effects. function estimates Random Effects Poisson-Lindley regression model using maximum likelihood. similar poisLind, includes additional terms account random effects. Random Effects Poisson-Lindley model useful panel data assumes random effects follow gamma distribution. PDF $$ f(y_{}|\mu_{},\theta)=\frac{\theta^2}{\theta+1} \prod_{t=1}^{n_i}\frac{\left(\mu_{}\frac{\theta(\theta+1)} {\theta+2}\right)^{y_{}}}{y_{}!} \cdot \frac{ \left(\sum_{t=1}^{n_i}y_{}\right)! \left(\sum_{t=1}^{n_i}\mu_{}\frac{\theta(\theta+1)}{\theta+2}       + \theta + \sum_{t=1}^{n_i}y_{} + 1\right) }{ \left(\sum_{t=1}^{n_i}\mu_{}\frac{\theta(\theta+1)}{\theta+2}       + \theta\right)^{\sum_{t=1}^{n_i}y_{}+2} } $$ log-likelihood function : $$ LL = 2\log(\theta) - \log(\theta+1)   + \sum_{t=1}^{n_i} y_{}\log(\mu_{})   + \sum_{t=1}^{n_i} y_{}\log\!\left(       \frac{\theta(\theta+1)}{\theta+2}     \right)   - \sum_{t=1}^{n_i}\log(y_{}!)   + \log\!\left(       \left(\sum_{t=1}^{n_i}y_{}\right)!     \right)   + \log\!\left(       \sum_{t=1}^{n_i}\mu_{}\frac{\theta(\theta+1)}{\theta+2}       + \theta + \sum_{t=1}^{n_i}y_{} + 1     \right)   - \left(\sum_{t=1}^{n_i}y_{} + 2\right)     \log\!\left(       \sum_{t=1}^{n_i}\mu_{}\frac{\theta(\theta+1)}{\theta+2}       + \theta     \right) $$ mean variance : $$\mu_{}=\exp(X_{} \beta)$$ $$ V(\mu_{})=\mu_{}+ \left(1-\frac{2}{(\theta+2)^2}\right)\mu_{}^2 $$

text: Generates predictions expected count (lambda) observations. countreg.rp (Random Parameters) models, three methods available: Simulated: Uses Halton draws simulate random   parameters averages outcomes. simulation-based   approximation. Individual: Estimates observation-specific coefficients   (conditional observed outcomes) using Empirical Bayes. Requires   outcome variable present data. Exact: Uses analytical Moment Generating Functions   (MGFs) random parameter distributions calculate exact   expected value. method faster removes simulation error. countreg, poisLindRE, RENB models, function calculates expected value \(\mu = \exp(X\beta)\) (appropriate adjustments specific families like PLN underreporting).

code: # \donttest{ # Load data and create a dummy variable data("washington_roads") washington_roads$AADT10kplus <- ifelse(washington_roads$AADT > 10000, 1, 0)  # ========================================================================= # 1. Fixed Parameter Model (countreg) # ========================================================================= nb2_fixed <- countreg(Total_crashes ~ lnaadt + lnlength + speed50,                       data = washington_roads,                        family = "NB2") pred_fixed <- predict(nb2_fixed, data = washington_roads)  # ========================================================================= # 2. Random Parameters Model (countreg.rp) # ========================================================================= rp_nb2 <- countreg.rp(Total_crashes ~ lnaadt + lnlength,                       rpar_formula = ~ -1 + speed50,                       data = washington_roads,                       family = "NB2",                       rpardists = c(speed50 = "n"),                       ndraws = 100)  # Method A: Simulated (Default) pred_sim <- predict(rp_nb2, data = washington_roads, method = "Simulated")  # Method B: Exact (Analytical MGF) pred_exact <- predict(rp_nb2, data = washington_roads, method = "Exact")  # ========================================================================= # 3. title: Create a Table Comparing Regression Models with AIC, BIC, and McFadden's Pseudo-R-Squared — regCompTable
code: # Comparing the NBP model with the NB2 and NB1 models data("washington_roads") washington_roads$AADTover10k <- ifelse(washington_roads$AADT>10000,1,0)  nb.1 <- countreg(Total_crashes ~ lnaadt + lnlength + speed50 +                     ShouldWidth04 + AADTover10k,                     data=washington_roads, family = 'NB1', method = 'NM')                      nb.2 <- countreg(Total_crashes ~ lnaadt + lnlength + speed50 +                     ShouldWidth04 + AADTover10k,                     data=washington_roads, family = 'NB2', method = 'NM')                                           nb.p <- countreg(Total_crashes ~ lnaadt + lnlength + speed50 +                     ShouldWidth04 + AADTover10k,                     data=washington_roads, family = 'NBP', method = 'NM')                                           comptable <-   regCompTable(list("NB-1"=nb.1, "NB-2"=nb.2, "NB-P"=nb.p), tableType="latex") print(comptable) #> \begin{table} #>  #> \caption{Model Comparison Statistics} #> \centering #> \begin{tabular}[t]{llll} #> \toprule #> Parameter & NB-1 & NB-2 & NB-P\\ #> \midrule #> (Intercept) & -7.807 (0.041)*** & -7.151 (0.043)*** & -7.798 (0.043)***\\ #> lnaadt & 0.942 (0.005)*** & 0.866 (0.005)*** & 0.942 (0.005)***\\ #> lnlength & 0.821 (0.036)*** & 0.836 (0.037)*** & 0.834 (0.037)***\\ #> speed50 & -0.368 (0.093)*** & -0.401 (0.092)*** & -0.386 (0.094)***\\ #> ShouldWidth04 & 0.255 (0.056)*** & 0.231 (0.061)*** & 0.258 (0.059)***\\ #> \addlinespace #> AADTover10k & 0.649 (0.077)*** & 0.828 (0.093)*** & 0.686 (0.086)***\\ #> ln(alpha) & -1.714 (0.35)*** & -1.328 (0.283)*** & -1.327 (0.291)***\\ #> ln(p) & --- & --- & 0.499 (0.173)**\\ #> N Obs. & 1501 & 1501 & 1501\\ #> LL & -1065.086 & -1063.673 & -1062.266\\ #> \addlinespace #> AIC & 2144.172 & 2141.345 & 2140.533\\ #> BIC & 2181.37 & 2178.542 & 2183.044\\ #> Pseudo-R-Sq. & 0.301 & 0.302 & 0.303\\ #> \bottomrule #> \end{tabular} #> \end{table}

title: Compare Regression Models with Likelihood Ratio Test, AIC, and BIC — regCompTest
text: model fitted regression model object. data options data frame containing variables model. supplied, original data used estimate model used. basemodel character string specifying family base model compare (options include family countreg "Poisson"). Default "Poisson". variables Logical. TRUE, base model include variables provided model. FALSE, base model intercept-model. Default FALSE. print Logical. TRUE, table results shown. FALSE, table results printed console. ... Additional arguments passed base model fitting function - options argument countreg function.

title: Compare Regression Models with Likelihood Ratio Test, AIC, and BIC — regCompTest
text: list containing following components: LL Log-likelihood provided model. LLbase Log-likelihood base model. LR Likelihood Ratio statistic. LRdof Degrees freedom Likelihood Ratio test. AIC Akaike Information Criterion provided model. AICbase Akaike Information Criterion base model. BIC Bayesian Information Criterion provided model. BICbase Bayesian Information Criterion base model. LR_pvalue P-value Likelihood Ratio test. PseudoR2 McFadden's Pseudo R^2. statistics tibble format summary results. gtTable gt table object summarizing results. latexTable Latex code table summarizing results. htmlTable HTML table summarizing results.

title: Compare Regression Models with Likelihood Ratio Test, AIC, and BIC — regCompTest
text: function performs following steps: Fits base model, either Poisson regression another specified model. Computes log-likelihoods provided model base model. Calculates AIC BIC models. Conducts Likelihood Ratio test compare models (provided model parameters base model). Computes McFadden's Pseudo R^2. Likelihood-Ratio test computed $$LR = -2 (LL_{base \ model}-LL_{model})$$. test chi-squared degrees freedom $$dof=N_{model \ params}-N_{base \ mode \ params}$$. AIC calculated $$AIC = -2 \cdot LL + 2 \cdot nparam$$, BIC calculated $$BIC = -2 \cdot LL + nparam \cdot \log(n)$$.

title: Compare Regression Models with Likelihood Ratio Test, AIC, and BIC — regCompTest
code:

title: Estimate a Random Effects Negative Binomial regression model — renb

title: Estimate a Random Effects Negative Binomial regression model — renb
text: formula R formula. group_var grouping variable(s) random effects (e.g., individual ID panel ID variables). data dataframe variables formula. method method use optimization maximum likelihood estimation. options, see maxLik. Note "BHHH" available function due implementation random effects. max.iters maximum number iterations allow optimization method perform. print.level Integer specifying verbosity output optimization. bootstraps Optional integer specifying number bootstrap samples used estimating standard errors. specified, bootstrapping performed. offset optional offset term provided string.

title: Estimate a Random Effects Negative Binomial regression model — renb
text: function estimates random effects negative binomial (RENB) regression model. model based NB-1 model. PDF RENB : $$f(y_{}|\mu_{}, , b) =   \frac{\Gamma(+b) +     \Gamma(+ \sum_{t = 1}^{n_i} \mu_{}) +     \Gamma(b + \sum_{t=1}^{n_i}y_{})}     {\Gamma() \Gamma(b) \Gamma(+ b +        \sum_{t=1}^{n_i}\mu_{} + \sum_{t=1}^{n_i}y_{})} \prod_{t=1}^{n_i}        \frac{\Gamma(\mu_{}+y_{})}{\Gamma(\mu_{})\Gamma(y_{})}$$

title: Estimate a Random Effects Negative Binomial regression model — renb
code: # \donttest{ ## RENB Model data("washington_roads") washington_roads$AADTover10k <-    ifelse(washington_roads$AADT > 10000, 1, 0) # create a dummy variable renb.mod <- renb(Animal ~ lnaadt + speed50 + ShouldWidth04 + AADTover10k,                                 data=washington_roads,                                 offset = "lnlength",                                 group_var="ID",                                 method="nm",                                 max.iters = 1000) summary(renb.mod) #> Call: #>  Animal ~ lnaadt + speed50 + ShouldWidth04 + AADTover10k  #>  #>  Method:  RENB  #> Iterations:  746  #> Convergence:  successful convergence   #> Log-likelihood:  -263.7988  #>  #> Parameter Estimates: #> # A tibble: 8 × 7 #>   parameter           coeff `Std. what: Calculate Root Mean Squared Error (RMSE) — rmse
title: Calculate Root Mean Squared Error (RMSE) — rmse
text: function calculates Root Mean Squared Error (RMSE) observed predicted values.

title: Calculate Root Mean Squared Error (RMSE) — rmse
code: rmse(y, mu)

title: Calculate Root Mean Squared Error (RMSE) — rmse
text: y Numeric vector representing observed values. mu Numeric vector representing predicted values.

title: Calculate Root Mean Squared Error (RMSE) — rmse
text: Numeric value representing RMSE.

title: Calculate Root Mean Squared Error (RMSE) — rmse
text: RMSE calculated using formula: $$RMSE = \sqrt{\frac{1}{n} \sum_{=1}^{n} (y_i - \mu_i)^2}$$ \(y\) vector observed values \(\mu\) vector predicted values.
